snippet: Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China said the areas of agreement included “some important breakthroughs.”
abstract: United States and Chinese leaders announce important progress on a range of economic issues at annual bilateral meeting; China has agreed to remove some subsidies and favorable regulations affecting state-owned corporations and to allow foreigners to take bigger stakes in Chinese securities firms. Photo (M)d

byline.original: By MICHAEL WINES and ANNIE LOWREY; Michael Wines reported from Beijing and Annie Lowrey from Washington

lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- Leaders of China and the United States said Friday that they had made important progress on a range of economic issues at their annual bilateral meeting, with Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China saying the areas of agreement included ''some important breakthroughs.'' China agreed to remove what United States officials said were unfair subsidies and favorable regulations affecting state-owned corporations and to allow foreigners to take bigger stakes in Chinese securities firms, according to a senior official of the United States delegation who spoke on condition of anonymity.

headline.main: Progress Seen on Economic Issues in U.S.-China Talks
